quoteLast: a signal was given by one of their people. Every man had gnawed through his cord with his teeth during the darkness, and at the concerted cry in a language that no one understood, the entire party, of upwards of eighty men, knocked down the astonished guard, also the sentries, and rushed headlong over the rocks in the direction of Lobore.
title: Ismailia
author: Baker, Samuel White, Sir, 1821-1893

quoteLast: I dozed off, and the next thing I remember was a Turk leaning over me, trying, as I thought, to prod me in the face with a bayonet. I made a vicious kick at him which woke me up, and then I discovered that my Turk was no Turk at all but merely the hospital orderly, who was attempting to jab a thermometer into my mouth in an effort to take my temperature. It was 5 A. M.
title: With the Zionists in Gallipoli
author: Patterson, J. H. (John Henry), 1867-1947

quoteFirst: Firing became general all along the line accompanied by a heavy bombardment of the whole position, so that evidently this attack must have been pre-arranged. Musketry and machine-gun fire continued without interruption till after dark, and from then up to
title: Sir Ian Hamilton's Despatches from the Dardanelles, etc.
author: Hamilton, Ian, 1853-1947; Wood, Evelyn, 1838-1919 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: He could manage to get along all right on a smooth path, but rough going gave him great pain. Fortunately, the road we now struck had quite a fair surface and we made a good pace for the next two hours, assisted by the moon. Finally,
quoteLast: , we lay down for an hour, until dawn, near the side of the road. We found we had overslept ourselves on waking, as it was broad daylight; so we had to hurry off up a small hill and hide in the bushes.
title: A Kut Prisoner
author: Bishop, Harry Coghill Watson

title: My Memoirs
author: Steinheil, Marguerite, 1869-1954

quoteLast: ," said Chateau Renaud to D----, in a low voice.
title: The Corsican Brothers
author: Dumas, Alexandre, 1802-1870; Frith, Henry, 1840- [Translator]

quoteLast: and generally turning into camp between 6 and 7, long after the short winter afternoons had closed in, so that we had to find our way round our new camping ground in the dark. The weather had got considerably warmer, although the nights were still bitterly cold, and quite a scorching sun used to come out for a few hours in the middle of the day, and this took it out of the tired men a good deal.
title: An English woman-sergeant in the Serbian Army
author: Sandes, Flora, 1876-1956; Grujić, Slavko J., 1871-1937 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: There is a sharp, imperative rap on my outer door; a rap having within its insistent urgency a shadow of delicate diffidence, as though the person responsible were a trifle scared of the performance and on tiptoe to run away. I roll over and regard the clock. Four-forty. One of the dubious by-products of continuous service as a senior assistant at sea is the habit of waking automatically
quoteLast: This gives one several hours, when ashore, to meditate upon one's sins, frailties, and (more rarely) triumphs and virtues. For a man who gets up at say four-thirty is regarded with aversion ashore.
title: Modern Essays
author: Morley, Christopher, 1890-1957 [Editor]; Ayres, Harry Morgan, 1881-1948 [Contributor]; Beerbohm, Max, Sir, 1872-1956 [Contributor]; Belloc, Hilaire, 1870-1953 [Contributor]; Bone, David W. quoteFirst: Saturday, 23rd March, Brinkley Bluff, McDonnell Range. Heavy shower of rain
quoteLast: this morning. After sunrise it all cleared away and became fine. Started at 8.20 to cross the northern portion of the range by following the creek up.
title:

The Journals of John McDouall Stuart During the Years 1858, 1859, 1860, 1861, and 1862, When He Fixed the Centre of the Continent and Successfully Crossed It from Sea to Sea
author: Stuart, John McDouall, 1815-1866

quoteFirst: Sleep was impossible for any one on our boat; in fact, many feared to turn in at all, as they thought some of the plates of the boats might be stove in. We wandered about from cabin to deck, and from deck to cabin, trying in vain to get to sleep. The Spanish Chief Engineer came to us on the deck
title:
Five Months on a German Raider
Being the Adventures of an Englishman Captured by the 'Wolf'
author: Trayes, Frederic George, 1871-

quoteFirst: Oh, that good fellow, how he did work as if he had just begun his day instead of having been at it since
quoteLast: He helped me set up the beds, straighten up a living room, lit a fire, fetched some supper from a local pork butcher's, and at last with an earnest enquiry as to whether he couldn't do anything more for me, supposed he'd better be getting towards home as he had to be up at three the next morning.
title: Confessions of a Tradesman
author: Bullen, Frank Thomas, 1857-1915

quoteFirst: It was about half an hour before daylight, probably
quoteLast: , in the midst of a violent storm of wind and rain, that, under cover of darkness, the Americans began crossing the river.  They were seen by the militia sentinel on guard at Queenston, who immediately ran to the guardhouse to give the alarm.
title: General Brock
author: Edgar, Matilda Ridout, Lady, 1844-1910

quoteFirst: The two most revolutionary elements in naval warfare were present, but they cannot be said to have exerted any tactical effect on the battle. The limited use of the airplane has been told, and a Zeppelin was reported at
quoteLast: June 1, which may have observed the location of the British fleet. U-boats were reported early in the action, but there is no hint that they took any real part in the battle.

quoteFirst: Early one morning, a few days after Admiral Ho’s departure, the camp was roused by a sudden alarm.
quoteLast: , when it was still pitch dark, we were awakened by the sound of heavy firing in the Chinese territory. The continuous rattle of small arms and the deeper booming of field‐guns were distinctly audible.
title: The Land of the Boxers; or, China under the Allies

quoteLast: the President of the United States landed on the Mammouth Building in New York and was taken down in the elevator to the 110th floor to Supreme Commander Gordon's office. He found Colonel Edna Kennelworth sentinel at the door.
title: The tunnel thru the air
author: Gann, William D. (William Delbert), 1878-1955

quoteFirst: The guns at the moment were half a mile in rear. On looking intently, it seemed as if figures were moving in front of the fires. The time then was
quoteLast: Barker dismounted, and, taking two or three men with him, advanced on foot along the slope of the small ridge on the west of the mouth of the gorge to obtain a nearer view. Having satisfied himself the enemy was actually bivouacked on an old mealie garden, and in considerable force, exactly where the fires were, he proceeded to make his dispositions for attack, which, it was arranged, should begin as soon as daylight came.
title: A history of the Zulu Rebellion, 1906, and of Dinuzulu's arrest, trial, and expatriation
author: Stuart, James, 1868-1942

quoteFirst: I moved my bed into a magazine which was directly opposite to Cummings Point, and which was nearly empty. As I was sensible that the next three days would call for great physical exertion and constant wakefulness, I endeavored to get all the sleep I could on the night of the 11th.
quoteLast: on the 12th, I was awakened by some one groping about my room in the dark and calling out my name. It proved to be Anderson, who came to announce to me that he had just received a dispatch from Beauregard, dated 3.20 A.M., to the effect that he should open fire upon us in an hour.
title: Reminiscences of Forts Sumter and Moultrie in 1860-'61
author: Doubleday, Abner, 1819-1893
